parts.text:
```json
{
  "application": "BEAST1",
  "details": {
    "software": {
      "scheduler": "slurm",
      "spack": "0.17.3",
      "spack_instance": "gpu",
      "spack_instance_dir": "/cm/shared/apps/spack/0.17.3/gpu",
      "spack_package": "beast1@1.8.4",
      "spack_compiler": "gcc@8.5.0",
      "spack_variants": "+beagle",
      "spack_dependencies": "^libbeagle@3.1.2/$(spack find --format '{hash:7}' libbeagle@3.1.2 % ${SPACK_COMPILER})"
    },
    "resources": {
      "account": "sys200",
      "partition": "hotel-gpu",
      "nodes": 1,
      "tasks_per_node": 1,
      "cpus_per_task": 8,
      "gpu": "gpu1",
      "time": "00:30:00"
    }
  }
}
``` 

This script is primarily for running the BEAST1 application, a software package for Bayesian Evolutionary Analysis by Sampling Trees, using the Spack package manager. 

The script utilizes Slurm (Simple Linux Utility for Resource Management) for resource allocation and job management on a high-performance computing cluster. It leverages the Spack package manager to install and manage BEAST1, specifying the desired version (1.8.4) along with its dependencies, including libbeagle. 

The script configures the BEAST1 environment by loading necessary modules and setting up the Spack environment. It then installs BEAST1 using Spack's installation functionality, specifying the number of parallel jobs to utilize. After installation, it submits a new job to run the BEAST1 application (presumably 'beast1@1.10.4.sh') by utilizing Slurm's job dependency feature.

The script includes various environment variables for tracking the job details, system information, and software versions.
